titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brooklyn For Peace records 2016.026
titlestmt.author: Maggie Schreiner and Laura Juliano
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described with funding from the New York State Documentary Heritage Program. Additional funding was provided by the estate of John Fisk Robson.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-12-20 21:56:54 +0000.

physdesc.extent: in 40 manuscript boxes, 7 media boxes, 4 oversize rolls, 1 oversize flat box and 1 oversize flat file folder.

did.abstract: Brooklyn For Peace (BFP) was founded in 1984 as Brooklyn Parents for Peace by Charlotte Phillips and Carolyn Eisenberg, in response to the invasion of Grenada by the United States. Through public events, publicity campaigns, lobbying of elected officials, and demonstrations, Brooklyn For Peace works to eliminate war and the social injustices that are its causes. BFP's records reveal both the history of the organization as well as the broader grassroots response to a wide variety of significant social and political issues at the local, regional and national levels from the late twentieth century to the present.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Charlotte Phillips in 2016. A second accretion of material was delivered in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn For Peace records, 2016.026, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright to this collection is retained by Brooklyn For Peace.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Paper materials were housed in archival folders and boxes. Materials were physically grouped by subject, and duplicates were removed. All folder titles were supplied by the archivist, in consultation with Brooklyn For Peace. Scrapbook materials were removed from binders and plastic sleeves and placed in archival folders.
Please note that personal information, including email addresses, phone numbers and addresses are redacted throughout the collection. This was done by the donor prior to donation.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Duplicates of event flyers and routine correspondence were removed from the collection, as were newspaper and magazine clippings, receipts, blank forms, and other material not related to the interests and work of Brooklyn For Peace. Recordings of commerical broadcasts were removed from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The majority of this collection is open to research. A small portion of materials containing personally identifying information have been restricted, at the request of the donor, for a period of 30 years from the date of creation. Audiovisual material in this collection is not currently avaialble to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooklyn For Peace records document the founding and ongoing activities of a Brooklyn-based community organization, Brooklyn For Peace (formerly Brooklyn Parents for Peace), covering the years 1984-2018. With over thirty years of work as a New York-based activist organization, BFP's institutional records reveal both the history of the organization as well as the grassroots response to a wide variety of significant social and political issues at the local, regional and national levels from the late twentieth century to the present. In particular, the records document BFP's organizational structure, key campaigns and projects, public events, and petitions circulated. These topics are represented through meeting minutes, mailings, internal correspondence, financial records, audio-visual material, and event ephemera including flyers, artwork and banners. The collection also includes substantial documentation of other local, regional and international organizations and individuals, through extensive subject files collected by BFP's leadership. Social and political issues that are particularly well represented in the collection include the campaign for nuclear disarmament, anti-war organizing from the Gulf War through the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the Israel-Palestine conflict.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brooklyn For Peace (BFP) was founded in 1984 as Brooklyn Parents for Peace by Charlotte Phillips and Carolyn Eisenberg, in response to the invasion of Grenada by the United States. Since then, through public events, publicity campaigns, lobbying of elected officials, and demonstrations, Brooklyn For Peace has worked to eliminate war and the social injustices that are its causes. The organization works on domestic and international issues in an attempt to create a peaceful future. BFP operates as a membership-based, democratic, non-partisan, 501(c)3 corporation run by a Board of Directors.

Over the course of thirty years, BFP has worked on a wide range of issues pertaining to local, regional and international peace issues. BFP's committees have included: Arts and Culture, Anti-militarism (counter-recruitment), Climate Action, Darfur/Africa, Diversity and Outreach, Fundraising, International Law, Israel-Palestine, Latin America, Nuclear Zero, Peace and Economic Justice, Peace Fair, and UNICEF. There are several affiliated neighborhood-focused peace groups in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bay Ridge, Flatbush, Fort Greene, and Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. Regular efforts of BFP include organizing community meetings and forums, staffing information tables at relevant community and regional events, participating in phone and advertising campaigns, lobbying elected officials, participating in demonstrations, and providing didactic materials pertaining to targeted areas that fall within the mission of the organization.

BFP's earliest projects included organizing local opposition to a proposed Staten Island port for nuclear-capable cruise missiles, as well as protesting U.S. interventions in Central America and the 1991 Gulf War. Following September 11th, BFP advocated for the protection of civil liberties and opposed the detention of immigrants. In response to the No Child Left Behind Act in 2001, BFP sought to limit military recruiting in New York City public schools. This included distributing leaflets such as "How to Go to College Without Joining the Military."

BFP has organized against the wars in Iraq, Iran, Syria, Yemen, and Afghanistan, against police brutality in New York City, and for a peaceful solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. More recently, BFP has joined in community opposition to fracking, to the Rockaway Pipeline, and to the Liquefied Natural Gas port on Long Island. From 2003 until 2012 BFP hosted a regular Peace and Justice Fair. The Peace Fair included musical and theater performances, educational sessions and discussions, and was primarily intended as an outreach forum. In 2013 the event was replaced by the Pathmakers to Peace Gala. Additionally, since 2006 BFP has hosted a monthly program "War No More" on BRIC's Brooklyn Community Access TV station.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into five series:

physdesc.extent: in 12 manuscript boxes and 1 oversize folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials pertaining to the administration of Brooklyn fFor Peace from its founding in 1984 until the present. This includes correspondence and minutes of the Executive Board, committee correspondence and project files, and financial records and fundraising endeavors. Records from the Israel-Palestine Committee are particularly well represented. This series also includes general administrative records including correspondence regarding event endorsements, membership lists and special events, as well as office materials including organizational appointment books and notebooks. Finally, this series includes administrative records pertaining to the organization of the annual Peace Fair.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged into fice sub-series. Material has been grouped by subject and arranged alphabetically, with the exception of Sub-Series IA: Executive Board Meetings and Minutes, which is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Compiled by BFP leadership, this series includes 20 dated volumes of material representing the work of the organization, including events, meetings, discussions, interests, and conflicts. Material in this series consists primarily of event ephemera, newspaper clippings, informational pamphlets, correspondence, Brooklyn-based publications, and a small amount of administrative records. Volumes are organized by time period and cover BFP's involvement in the community throughout their existence, with a focus on the years 2003 through 2011. This series offers an overview of what BFP was doing in the community, what interested them as an organization, and what BFP's leadership felt was important to represent and document as an organization.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series has been arranged chronologically.

physdesc.extent: in 1 and a half manuscript boxes, 7 media boxes and 1 oversize folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials and recordings from events that BFP organized from their founding through 2018, addressing local, national, and international topics and conflicts. Ephemeral material in this series consists primarily of publicity mailings, event announcements and invitations, informational leaflets, program pamphlets, community outreach material, program and event descriptions and signs, as well as lobbying and propaganda material. Event recordings include cassettes, CD, VHS and DVD recordings of panel discussions, protests, and the Brooklyn Peace Fair. Subjects that are well represented are the Israel-Palestine conflict, the role of money in politics, local and national climate policy, and nuclear disarmament. Topics ranged from the local level, with interests such as the effort to shut down Indian Point, to international concerns in South Africa, Japan, Latin America, and the Middle East.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Ephemera has been grouped by subject and arranged alphabetically. Audio-visual records are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: War No More is a monthly television program produced by Brooklyn For Peace, and screened on the public access network Brooklyn Free Speech (BRIC channel 2). The show has aired since 2006, and includes interviews, event recordings and in-depth discussions of local, national and international political issues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged in episode order, with un-numbered recordings appearing at the end of the series.

physdesc.extent: in 13 manuscript boxes and 1 flat box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes material from a wide range of political organizations and individuals at the local, regional, national and international levels working on issues of interest to BFP. Material in this series consists primarily of publicity mailings and event ephemera, although there is a small amount of correspondence. Subjects that are well represented in this series include BFP's core issues of anti-war and militarism, nuclear disarmament, and the Israel-Palestine conflict. Other topics include racial justice in New York City, abolition, police brutality, and the conflict in Darfur, Sudan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials have been grouped by subject and arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this series consists of petitions signed and turned in to BFP to support their efforts to bring an end to local and international war and conflicts. These petitions contain biographical information including names, addresses, and phone numbers of the signees. Subjects that are well represented in this series include the War in Iraq, the Israel-Palestine conflict, biased New York Police Department practices, and a Nuclear-free New York City

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials have been grouped by subject and are arranged alphabetically.
